turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Candiru.
turn.1: What happened in the Lacerda case?
turn.2: In 1836 Eduard Poeppig documented a statement by a local physician in Pará, known only as Dr. Lacerda, who offered an eyewitness account of a case where a candiru had entered a human orifice.
turn.3: What happened after it entered the orifice?
turn.4: However, it was lodged in a native woman's vagina, rather than a male urethra.
turn.5: Was anyone able to remove the fish?
turn.6: He relates that the fish was extracted after external and internal application of the juice from a Xagua plant (believed to be a name for "Genipa americana").
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: Another account was documented by biologist George A.
turn.10: Boulenger from a Brazilian physician named Dr. Bach, who examined a man and several boys whose penises had been amputated.
turn.12: Bach believed this was a remedy performed because of parasitism by candiru, but he was merely speculating as he did not speak his patients' language.
